Some Major Blunders Have been made.
 
 Many of you may remember some of the events surrounding the missing hard drives at Los Alamos National Laboratory. Los Alamos has long been one of the world's most notorious outfits for nuclear research and development. Some of you might recognize the name Hanson, as he became the poster boy for high level espionage in the 21st century. Most thinking Americans were outraged at the slap on the wrist that Wen Ho Le received for his activities. Do any of you remember hearing stories about Mr. Deutch, head of the CIA from 1995-1996?
 
 Apparently, Mr. Deutch took classified information home with him and stored high level documents on the hard drive of his home computer. To make matters worse, his home computer was linked to the internet at that time. Anybody who is familiar with online vulnerabilities can attest to the stupidity of such an act. Furthermore, the head of the CIA should be well versed in the capabilities of computer hackers and foreign spies. Of couse, any agent of the government has a higher probablility of having his home lines tapped into by foreign intelligence, but the director of the CIA should expect it. One must ask whether or not this stupidity was deliberate, especially now, after the Hansen case was so widely publicized. If Russian diplomats are able to bug State Department offices, one can only assume they have the assets available to compromise a civilian's home security.
 
 Stories like this became more prevalent during the era of the Clintonistas. High level security breeches have become commonplace. Even more alarming is the government's unwillingness to prosecute these crimes to the fullest extent of the law. If nobody pays for gross imcompetence, or even deliberate misconduct regarding our nation's national security, one can only expect further violations. I remember reading about low level spies that were killed for lesser offenses during the cold war. 
 
 We have already seen the trickle down effect that the Los Alamos incident has caused regarding nuclear proliferation in the world, for it is no coincidence that China's ability to target any one of our American cities correlates to abuses in handling classified information. Such destructive technology is demonstrating a trickle down effect, as Chinas has sold its older technologies to irresponsible parties, like Pakistan, North Korea, and possibly Iran. As a result, the United States finds itself in a position where it must face the long term effects of such negligence for years to come. What kind of results must we endure before we once again decide to get tough on crimes of espionage? What should the penalty be for espionage, and/or negligence in handling classified information?
